isis.stitle: DT/DTA-466 Diesel Engine Service (1990) - VIBRATION DAMPER, CRANKSHAFT, MAIN BEARINGS, FLYWHEEL AND CRANKCASE - DAMPER, CRANKSHAFT AND MAIN BEARINGS (RECONDITIONING) - CRANKSHAFT AND MAIN BEARINGS

step1.para: Rotate the engine stand so the crankshaft is facing up.

Verify main bearing bolt torque as follows: (Refer to Figure 7.36
).
Place a socket over the main bearing bolt, then mark the socket and a point on the main bearing cap so the marks are aligned.

figure.caption: Figure 7.36. Check Bolt Torque (Using Pull-to-the-Mark Method).

step1.para: Using a breaker-bar, loosen the bolt 1/8 of a turn.
Without disturbing the socket location, remove the breaker-bar and install a torque wrench in its place.
Turn the bolt until the socket mark and main bearing cap mark is aligned.
With marks aligned, record the torque reading.
Remove the six (6) main bearing caps as follows:

note.para: Prior to main bearing cap removal, check to see that the caps and crankcase are stamped to identify location. If they are not marked, stamp in numerical order 1-7, starting with No.1 at the front of the engine. Stamp the crankcase oil pan rail and main bearing caps on the camshaft side. Refer to Figure 7.37.

step1.para: Loosen the main bearing cap bolts.

Grasp the bolts and rock the bearing cap back and forth to loosen and remove the cap. Refer to Figure 7.38
.
Remove the lower bearing shell from the cap and keep in order for inspection.
Remove the No. 7 rear (thrust) bearing as follows:

step2.para: Grasp the two bolts and rock the thrust bearing from side to side to loosen.

figure.caption: Figure 7.37. Verify Proper Bearing Cap Location.

step1.para:
Once loosened, remove the cap and bearing shell from the crankshaft. Refer to Figure 7.39
.

Remove the crankshaft from the crankcase using SE-2722 lifting sling, as shown in Figure 7.40
.

note.para: BE CAREFUL NOT TO DAMAGE THE CRANKSHAFT WHEN REMOVED.

step1.para:
Remove the upper main bearing shells by pushing them out of the main bearing saddle with your thumbs as shown in Figure 7.41
. Mark the upper shells and put with the lower shells until a proper inspection can be done.
